text:
Hi everyone !
Alyssia here, currently doing a PhD in France on electric power systems. I’ve been programming in Julia for almost three years now, implementing asynchronous distributed algorithms (economic dispatch and optimal power flow). Nice to meet you all!

elements.text:
Hi everyone !
Alyssia here, currently doing a PhD in France on electric power systems. I’ve been programming in Julia for almost three years now, implementing asynchronous distributed algorithms (economic dispatch and optimal power flow). Nice to meet you all!

text: Sounds neat! I have no idea what that is, but are you aware of Invenia? Sounds at least superficially similar to what they do... :invenia: (cc <@U6A936746>)

elements.text: Sounds neat! I have no idea what that is, but are you aware of Invenia? Sounds at least superficially similar to what they do...

text:
There are a lot of people doing great power stuff in Julia.

Yes, Invenia, (I think we are the largest that is doing everything in julia. I think mostly others are smaller groups in much much bigger orgs)
Another private company is  PSR (<@UP07UDESF>) is a pretty big company in Bazil doing a ton of things, some of which are in Julia

A bunch of individual people and individual universities doing PhDs (e.g. <@U82RE6STE> graduated last year)
PUC-Rio, Laboratory of Applied Mathematical Programming and Statistics has done a bunch of things.

Several US national labs have worked on large tools
Los Almos (PowerModels.jl)
NREL  (PowerSystems.jl,  a bunch of other stuff <@UE1U0U2MD>)
Argonne (UnitCommitment.jl)

There is a basically a session on power grid stuff  stuff every JuliaCon,
and it is a 1/3rd the talks a JuMP-dev workshop.

I recommend joining the <#CNEGS2YF5|jump-dev-bridged> even if not using JuMP.
